media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 14th May 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices -
Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
Welcome and lighting of peace candle (Duty Elder)
Call to worship
HYMN I know that my Redeemer lives [Tune: Church Triumphant] Prayers of adoration and confession The Lord’s Prayer
All age Talk:
HYMN Praise and thanksgiving [Tune: Bunessan (Morning has broken)]
Dedication of the offertory
Introduction to today’s readings Reading: Zechariah 8:1-13 read by Larry Reading: Revelation 21:22 – 22:5 read by Rosemary
HYMN In Christ there is no east or west [Tune: St Bernard] Sermon
HYMN Lord, thy Church on earth is seeking [Tune: Abbots Leigh]
Prayers of intercession
HYMN There’s wideness in God’s mercy [Tune: Sussex]
Final prayer and Benediction - Organ music after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 7th May 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices -
09:47 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
10:01 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (Duty Elder)
12:03 - Call to worship (inspired by Psalm 31) Christ is our rock, our fortress, who leads us and guides us. Therefore let us be strong; let our hearts take courage, for the Lord has rescued and saved us. Thanks be to God.
12:32 - 14:38 - HYMN R&S 469 - As we are gathered, Jesus is here (x2)
14:40 - Opening Prayers
16:45 - 27:10 - All age Talk: ‘The day after the Coronation’ Did anyone watch or attend the coronation. Past coronations, including that of King George and Queen Mary in 1911. There are two women alive who were born around the time of the 1911 coronation. My granddaughter slept through the recent coronation. Many people watched the coronation of King George VI in 1937 and Queen Elizabeth II in 1953. The history of the monarchy and the republic in England. Memories of the recent coronation and what was special about it. The horses, lifeguards, and mounties in the coronation procession. Christian Aid week and the importance of ordinary people in making a difference. Everyone is important to God, not just VIPs.
27:46 - 29:05 - NATIONAL ANTHEM God save the gracious King R&S 762 God save our gracious King! Long live our noble King! God save the King! Send him victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the King! Thy choicest gifts in store On him be pleased to pour, Long may he reign. May he defend our laws, And ever give us cause, To sing with heart and voice, God save the King!
Shared blessing with Junior Church Adults: May the Lord be with you Junior Church: And also with you. AMEN.
29:10 - 30:32 - Introduction to today’s readings
30:38 - 32:46 - Reading: 1 Peter 2.2 – 10 NIVUK read by Abigail Lokko
33:10 - 34:31 - HYMN R&S 264 He is Lord he is Lord (vs 1 and 2) sung seated
34:49 - 36:18 - Reading John 14. 1 – 10 (The Message) Linda Curley
36:26 - HYMN R&S 264 He is Life (vs 3 and 4) sung seated
37:54 - 46:53 - Short Address Different people in the church have varying reactions to the coronation ceremony. Some appreciate the colorful uniforms, vestments, and rituals, while others prefer something simpler. There is a mix of emotions, including discomfort when the ritual becomes disconnected from Jesus on the cross. King Charles, like any human being, experienced nervousness and anxiety during the anointing. The greater truth of the ceremony is that Jesus is exalted above all, and every knee should bow to him. The readings draw us into the wonder of who Jesus is and how he brings us to the Divine reality. "God Save the King" reminds us that we all need saving, and God has a part to play in our nation. King Charles has a representative role that goes beyond politics and arguments. The speaker hopes that King Charles will preserve the nation's laws and diversity. The letter of Peter reminds us to draw spiritual sustenance from God's love. The sharing of the Lord's Supper reminds us that we all need sustenance and to draw close to God. We carry burdens on our shoulders, but we can come to God's table to be sustained. The Lord is good, and we can taste that goodness and carry it with us. All the time, God is good, and we can draw close to Jesus to experience his goodness.
46:57 - 51:51 - Prayers for the world, our nation and each other Lord in your mercy hear our prayer.
52:19 - 54:50 - HYMN R&S 474 Brother, sister
54:53 - Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ. A Prayer of thanksgiving and Lord’s Prayer
58:23 - Distribution of bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice)
01:03:59 - Closing Prayer ALL Lord Jesus, we thank you for the gifts we have shared at your table; and the love you have poured into our hearts. We thank you for the nation, of which we are Part, and the peace and freedom we enjoy. We thank for the promise of your kingdom, where justice, truth and compassion will flow like a mighty river. Use our praying and living, this and everyday for the work of Jesus, here and now, caring, healing and restoring our world. Amen.
01:04:53 - 01:08:31 - HYMN R&S 603 Lord for the years
01:08:31 - 01:09:07 - Blessing
01:09:35 - 01:12:07 - Organ music after the service
#Church #Worship #Sing #Organ #Faithful #Jesus #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Blessings #GoodNews #NIV #NIVUK #Bible #Lessons #King #GoodNews #Hymns #AllAreWelcome #JoinIn #Christian #WarmSpace #WednesdayCafe #RejoiceandSing #Compassion #Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 30th April 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices -
09:13 - Entry of the Bible
09:17 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle
10:45 - Call to worship Shout for joy to the LORD, all the earth. Worship the LORD with gladness; Come before God with joyful songs. Know that the LORD is God. It is God who made us, and we are his; ; we are God’s people, the sheep of his pasture. Enter God’s gates with thanksgiving and his courts with praise; Give thanks to God and praise his name. God’s love endures forever.
11:31 - 13:15 - Hymn - I will enter his gates (sung twice)
13:23 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
15:46 - 24:54 - Introduction for all ages: ‘Recognise that voice?’ Missing Easter at Trinity due to scheduling conflicts. During Good Friday, the church had stations of prayer, including one titled "The Buried Grain," where people were invited to plant a pinch of seed into a tray of soil. This links to the Bible verse where Jesus compares his death to a buried grain that produces new life. The speaker sees the growth of the planted seeds as a symbol of Jesus' love within us, reverberating down the centuries and producing fruit in the lives of billions of people. The Bee Squared program (https://zeroch.org/bee-squared/) that encourages people to plant wildflowers to support bees and other insects crucial to life. Jesus is referred to as the Good Shepherd and the gateway to God's loving presence. Jesus' sheep recognize and trust his voice, and the speaker asks the audience to think of a voice they trust, like Mary Berry's recipe or Winston Churchill's wartime speeches. There are many voices out there today, and the speaker urges the audience to choose which voices they trust.
Reading: John 10.1 – 10 NIVUK read by Kitty
27:49 - Prayer Lord you are the Way – help us to follow. You are the truth – help us to listen. You are the Life – refresh our lives today. Amen.
28:24 - 30:23 - Hymn - Jesus stand among us
30:44 - 31:33 - Reading: Psalm 23 NIVUK read by Kate
31:41 - 39:44 - Meditation on the 23 rd Psalm – ‘being a follower of the Good Shepherd’ (using Stuart Townend sung version MP 1008) Sing verse 1 Leader: Let us think about how Jesus leads us in times past and in the present time. (pause) Let us think about the life Jesus offers us, life in abundance. (pause, then sing the chorus) Sing verse 2 Leader: Let us think about and receive again the inner peace offered by Jesus. (pause) Let us think about and receive again the contentment Jesus offers. (pause, then sing the chorus) Sing verse 3 Leader: Let us think about Jesus’ presence in difficult times holding before him our troubles and concerns. (pause) Let us think about drawing closer to Jesus and receiving his love and protection from harm. (pause, then sing the chorus)
40:21 - 41:26 - Reading: John 10.11 – 16 NIVUK read by Kitty
42:06 - 43:17 - Hymn The King of love vs 1 and 6 only -sung seated
43:54 - 56:30 - Address The Great "I ams" Jesus describes himself as "I am" seven times in John's Gospel. Each description ("I am the Good Shepherd," "I am the bread of life," etc.) takes us into the heart of who Jesus is. "I am" is not just a personal description but echoes God's words to Moses in the desert. In John's Gospel, "I am" is linked to the fundamentals of life. The Shepherd lies down in front of the entrance and protects the sheep through the night. This intimate picture of the Shepherd is full of trust and care. Jesus is the Good Shepherd who knows us through and through and wants to protect and keep us safe. The Gate is the cross, where Jesus protects, leads, and opens up heaven and God's love to us. Jesus is both the king of kings and the outcast, the one who is poor and rejected.
56:44 - 58:33 - Hymn- All heaven declares
58:41 - 01:05:55 - Prayers for the world with the response God of truth and love, bring them abundant life.
01:06:14 - 01:09:32 - Hymn - Christ is the King! O friends rejoice
01:09:33 - 01:09:58 - Closing blessing
01:10:25 - 01:14:32 - Organ music after the service
#Church #Worship #Sing #Organ #Faithful #Jesus #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Blessings #GoodNews #NIV #NIVUK #Bible #Lessons #King #GoodNews #Hymns #AllAreWelcome #JoinIn #Christian #WarmSpace #WednesdayCafe #RejoiceandSing #Compassion #Lent

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 23rd April 2023
media:group.media:description:
Opening music, photos, and notices - Missing in this stream
Entry of the Bible - Missing in this stream
Welcome and lighting of peace candle (Duty Elder) - Missing in this stream
Call to worship Psalm 116:8-9 - Missing in this stream
Hymn: R&S 260 – Christ is alive! Let Christians sing (Tune: Truro) - Missing in this stream
Opening Prayers of Approach, Thanksgiving, Confession & Praise, and the Lord’s Prayer - Missing in this stream
Introduction to the Bible reading - Missing in this stream
00:00:00 - Reading: Luke 24: 13-35 (CEV)
02:05 - 04:00 - Talk for all ages How long ago did you last play hide and seek? Jesus walking with the disciples, hidden in plain sight. Jesus was not noticed by the disciples when he was walking with them. We can sometimes be so focused on our own problems that we don't see the miracles or the ordinary everyday things that are right in front of us. We should pray that God will open our eyes and our hearts to see him in ways that we don't expect.
04:05 - 07:08 - Hymn: R&S 234 Alleluia, alleluia, give thanks to the risen Lord (tune: Alleluia)
07:23 - Dedication of gifts
08:12 - Blessing as Junior Church go to their activities: Adults: May the Lord be with you Junior Church: And also with you All: Amen
08:28 - Introduction to the Bible reading
09:20 - Reading: Acts 2:14-24, 37-42 (CEV)
12:34 - 15:25 - Hymn: R&S 354 Come Living God, when least expected (tune: Sunset)
15:35 - 22:13 - Talk: Expect the unexpected followed by a time of quiet reflection We all make plans Sometimes plans don't go as expected. It can be difficult to deal with unexpected events. Faith in God can help us deal with unexpected events. The story of the Road to Emmaus shows how Jesus can come alongside us in unexpected ways. We should be open to expecting the unexpected. We should pray for those who are struggling. We should have faith in God, even when things don't go our way. The story of the Road to Emmaus shows how Jesus can come alongside us in unexpected ways, and give us hope when we are struggling. We should be grateful for God's presence in our lives, and pray for those who are struggling. We should renew our commitment to discipleship, and live our lives in a way that honors God. Have faith in God, even when things don't go your way.
22:29 - 25:08 - Hymn: R&S 590 – In heavenly love abiding (tune: Penlan)
25:25 - 27:29 - Prayers for others and ourselves led by Sue Thorne
27:53 - 30:19 - Hymn: R&S 558 – Will you come and follow me (Tune: Kelvingrove)
30:25 - Time of silent prayer
33:32 - 33:49 - Closing blessing
34:18 - 38:07 - Music, notices, and photographs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 16th April 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
06:32 - Entry of Bible 06:44 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
08:13 - Call to worship This service will be like the TV program #ILiterallyJustToldYou
10:12 - 13:15 - Hymn - R&S 74 - Praise to the Lord
13:20 - Opening Prayers (prompt) Unlock our hearts to you, Lord. (Response) May we stop doubting and believe.
Lord’s Prayer
Introduction to the service
17:40 - 21:58 - Hymn - R&S 258 - Saviour who exalted high
22:04 - Talk (part 1) Who can remember the first word of the hymn we have just sung - #WeLiterallyJustSangIt
22:46 - 26:41 - Hymn - R&S 499 - Have faith in God my heart
Introduction to Bible readings
28:20 - 29:55 - Reading: 1 Peter 1. v3-9 (Read by Sue )
30:36 - 33:02 - Hymn - R&S 588 - Blest be the everlasting God)
33:13 - 36:23 - Reading: John 20. v19-31 (Read by John)
36:36 - 41:04 - Talk (part 2) The words "faith", "family", and "staff" to illustrate the importance of support. A stick can help people get through muddy fields. Workers support their bosses. Music supports Charles so he knows what to play in what order. In India, wooden sticks are used as scaffolding. People need support in different ways. We should all be there to support each other.
41:46 - 44:34 - Hymn - My Faith it is an oaken staff
45:00 - 46:19 - Prayers for others and ourselves
47:05 - 50:25 - Hymn - R&S 244 - O sons & daughters let us sing - v6 - 11 (Tune - Victory - 250)
50:26 - 51:01 - Closing blessing

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Easter Sunday, 9th April 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
10:51 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
11:04 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
13:08 - Call to Worship
14:17 - 19:21 - Hymn R&S 232 Christ the Lord is risen today
19:27 - Opening Prayers
22:04 - 24:40 - Reading: John 20. 1 – 18 NIVUK
24:53 - 30:04 - Talk for all ages Eggs have been given during this time of year before Christianity because it represents new life in spring. Jesus' new life is different from a physical life because he is outside of time and space. To change and experience new life, one must break out of their shell, just as a chick must peck out of an egg. God calls us to live a loving life and trust in Him, which may require breaking out of our old habits and fears. Jesus has already broken through death and sin, and through Him, we can find a new life. The Easter message is that Jesus' resurrection brings new life and the possibility of eternal life.
30:14 - 32:44 - Hymn R&S 246: The day of resurrection
33:12 - 34:46 - Reading: Acts 10. 34 – 43 NIVUK read by Sarah and Samuel Evans
35:01 - 37:51 - Hymn R&S 250 The strife is o’er, the battle done
37:57 - 46:11 - Address The power of first impressions. A TV advert that illustrates the importance of getting the full picture before making judgments. First impressions can lead to error and prejudice. The Easter story and the power of first impressions. Mary Magdalene's initial impression upon finding the empty tomb was reasonable. Peter and John rushed to verify Mary's report but only saw that the body was gone. Mary stayed at the tomb and encountered Jesus again. The wonder and mystery of the Resurrection are beyond human understanding. Waiting on God and risking vulnerability can lead to a deeper understanding of truth. The truth of the Resurrection is that Jesus Christ is risen.
46:26 - 50:28 - Hymn - R&S 107 The love of God comes close
50:36 - Communion – We invite you to share in the bread and wine united in the name of Christ. A Prayer of thanksgiving Distribution of bread and wine
01:01:43 - Prayer
01:03:14 - Hymn R&S 264 He is Lord (vs 1 only)
01:04:21 - Prayers of intercession and The Lord’s Prayer
01:07:46 - 01:11:06 - Hymn R&S 262 Crown him with many crowns
01:11:06 - 01:11:34 - Blessing
01:12:08 - 01:16:12 - Music, photos , and notices after the service

entry.title: United Free Church Good Friday Worship - High Wycombe - 7th April 2023

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: United Free Church Good Friday Worship - High Wycombe - 7th April 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
06:13 - Welcome 07:30 - Introduction and call to worship (from Isaiah 53 and John 1.29)
He was despised and rejected a man of suffering and acquainted with grief; he was despised, and held of no account.
All: Yet he was wounded for our transgressions, crushed for our iniquities;
Upon him was the punishment that made us whole, and by his bruises we are healed. All we like sheep have gone astray; we have all turned to our own way, and the LORD has laid on him the iniquity of us all.
Behold the lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world. Thanks be to God for the cross of Christ, Sign of God’s love for the world. We offer our thanks and praise this good and holy day. Amen.
08:37 - 10:34 - Hymn - In the cross of Christ I glory
10:39 - Introduction to the readings and Opening Prayer Following the account of Matthew who uses the Gospel of Mark as the basis for the story and adds his own details about that fearsome yet glorious day.
12:39 - 15:19 - Reading: Matthew 27.11 – 26
15:31 - 22:42 - Brief Reflection and Prayer of confession
22:57 - 27:54 - Song - My song is love unknown
28:04 - 30:17 - Reading: Matthew 27. 27 – 44
30:26 - 36:10 - Brief Reflection and Prayer for those who suffer today
37:33 - 40:58 - Hymn - How deep the Father’s love for us
41:09 - 43:24 - Reading: Matthew 27. 45 – 56
43:33 - 49:40 - Brief Reflection and Prayer of thanks
49:52 - Hymn - When I survey the wondrous cross
53:18 - Prayers for the world
01:00:03 - Hymn In Christ alone
01:03:42 - May the cross of Christ uphold you; The love of Christ surround you; The peace of Christ guard you and fill this hurting world Amen
01:04:29 - 01:07:05 - Music after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 2nd April 2023 - Palm Sunday

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 2nd April 2023 - Palm Sunday
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
01:31 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
10:47 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder) - No sound
01:34 - Hymn - All glory laud and honour
04:30 - Opening Prayer with the response: …we proclaim Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest heaven!
08:20 - Introduction: ‘Across the world today – water and crosses’ Palm crosses are a symbol of Jesus' entry into Jerusalem because they are made from palm leaves, which were used to welcome Jesus into the city. Palm crosses are a symbol of victory because they represent Jesus' victory over death. Palm crosses are a reminder of Jesus' suffering and death because they represent the cross that Jesus was crucified on. Palm crosses are a symbol of hope and new life because they represent Jesus' resurrection. Palm crosses can be recycled or composted because they are made from natural materials. WaterAid is a charity that provides clean water and sanitation to people in need around the world. Sado is a girl from Ethiopia who had to walk five hours to collect water every day because she lived in a village that did not have access to clean water. Malala is a girl from Madagascar who can now go to school because of a water tap in her village. The water tap was installed by WaterAid. Palm crosses are a symbol of our connection to the world church and to people in need around the world because they are made by people in Tanzania and used by Christians all over the world.
Taizé chant: ‘We adore you, Lord Jesus Christ’ (recording)
A prayer for all ages together
31:57 Hymn - Make way! Make way!
Introduction to the reading
Reading: Philippians 2.5-11 NIVUK read by Norma
44:38 - 46:15 - Hymn - My song is love unknown (vs. 1 and 2 only) 46:25 - Prayer
46:56 - 55:33 - Short Address You don't need a long sermon, you just need a Palm Cross to connect you with the world church A palm cross connects us with the World Church and with the crowd that welcomed Jesus on Palm Sunday. The crowd that welcomed Jesus was a mixture of people, some curious, some caught up in the Jesus movement, and some who wanted something new. Jesus's entry into Jerusalem was a protest against the way things were, with Roman and religious authorities pressing down on the people. Jesus's entry into Jerusalem was also a celebration of an alternative way of life, based on love and justice. The crowd welcomed Jesus with palm branches and cloaks, symbolizing their willingness to lay down their lives for him. Jesus's death on the cross was a sacrifice for the sins of the world and a victory over hatred and division. We are called to follow Jesus's example of humility, love, and forgiveness. We are called to work for justice and peace in the world. Palm Sunday is a time to reflect on the meaning of Jesus's life and death and to commit ourselves to following him. Palm Sunday is a time to celebrate the hope and joy that Jesus brings to the world.
55:34 - Prayer of Dedication of all our gifts Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ.
56:57 - HYMN Broken for me, broken for you
01:00:46 - A Prayer of thanksgiving and Lord’s Prayer
01:03:58 - Distribution of bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice)
01:09:20 - Closing Prayer ALL Lord Jesus, We thank you for the gifts we have shared at your table, and the love we have received from you. As we enter this Holy Week, deepen our love for you our trust in your promises and our hope for this world. Renew us for the work for your kingdom of truth and love, justice and peace, to the glory of God. Amen.
01:10:34 - 01:12:30 - Hymn - Ride on ride on
01:12:35 - 01:13:13 - Blessing
We are making donations today to https://w0025000ww.wateraid.org/uk/
01:13:44 - 01:16:53 - Music, photos , and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 26th March 2023 - 5th Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 26th March 2023 - 5th Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
10:35 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
10:47 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
12:43 -Call to worship Minister: We have come to worship God. All: We gather to offer praise and thanksgiving. Minister: We come listening out for God's word in scripture and praise. All: We come seeking his strength and guidance for a new week. Minister: Jesus said: Whoever wants to be my disciple, All: Let them take up their cross and follow me. Minister: The Lord be with you All: And also with you.
13:27 - 16:31 - Hymn R&S 292 When morning gilds the skies
16:39 - 23:08 - Opening Prayers of Praise and Confession Including Hymn R&S 528 : Jesus, good above all others The Lord's Prayer
23:11 - 27:20 - Introductory Talk What makes us human? What helps bring people down to earth? What makes people human is their ability to connect with others and to show compassion. We are all connected, even if we don't always feel it. We should never underestimate the power of a simple act of kindness. The Queen, Tony Blair, and the Bishop of Birmingham are all examples of how humanity can be seen in everyday life. The story of Lazarus shows how Jesus' humanity intrudes in the most interesting way. Jesus is not just a divine being, but also a human being who can understand and empathize with our suffering. We should always strive to connect with others and to show compassion. Even the smallest act of kindness can make a difference in someone's life. We should never forget that we are all human and that we should treat each other with respect and dignity. The world would be a better place if we all made an effort to be more human.
27:37 - 30:49 - Hymn MP 799 All I once held dear
30:56 - Blessing as Junior Church go to their activities: Adults: May the Lord be with you Junior Church: And also with you All: Amen
Bible Readings 32:10 - Psalm 130 - HYMN R&S 728
33:37 - 39:17 - John 11: 1-45 read by David and Valerie Bishop Reader 1 verses 1-7, 17-27,38-46 Reader 2 verses 7-16, 28-37
39:43 - 41:55 - Hymn R&S 518 Father, I place into your hands
42:02 - 56:45 - Sermon (followed by time of quiet reflection) The story of Lazarus is a story of hope, as it shows that even in the darkest of times, there is always the possibility of resurrection. Jesus is human and experiences grief, as he weeps for Lazarus. This shows that Jesus is not just a divine being, but also a human being who can understand and empathize with our suffering. Jesus is the resurrection and the life, as he raises Lazarus from the dead. This shows that Jesus has the power to overcome death and bring new life to those who believe in him. The story of Lazarus is a sign of God's glory, as it shows that God is powerful and can bring new life out of death. We should raise our awareness of signs of hope, as there are many things in the world that give us hope, even in the midst of difficult times. We should empower our community to do the same, as we can all work together to spread hope and light in the world. We should wait patiently for the resurrection, as we know that one day Jesus will return and make all things new. We should not be afraid to weep, as it is natural to feel grief when we lose someone we love. We should trust in Jesus, as he is the only one who can truly give us hope and life. We should believe in the resurrection, as it is the foundation of our faith and the hope of our salvation.
57:28 - 01:00:13 - Hymn R&S 651 O God, by whose almighty plan
01:00:23 - 01:05:34 - Prayers for others and ourselves
01:05:50 - 01:09:26 - Hymn R&S 503 It is a thing most wonderful (Tune: Herongate)
01:09:39 - 01:10:23 - Closing Blessing
01:10:50 - 01:13:25 - Music, photos , and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 19th March 2023 - 4th Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 19th March 2023 - 4th Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
00:06:08 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
06:19 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
07:57 - Call to worship Leader: Let us worship the Living God, Women: who is mother Men: and father, Women: loving saviour Men: and faithful friend, Leader: alpha and omega, All: the beginning and the end, Leader: life and being beyond all we can imagine. All: We come to worship our God.
09:12 - 12:17 - Hymn R&S 74 Praise to the Lord
12:37 - 16:14 - Introduction: How do you pray? How do you see, imagine or name the immortal, invisible God? Thinking about how we picture God on Mothering Sunday. Different names for God, such as Lord Almighty, King of Creation, and Alpha and Omega. God is referred to as our Father in Heaven and Father of All. Jesus is a way to think about who God is. God is described as a friend, savior, and someone to speak to. There are many ways to think about and pray to God. Love is a key aspect of God's nature. If our picture of God is not loving, we are missing the mark
16:16 - Introduction to the reading
17:31 - 18:20 - 1 st Reading: Psalm 131 (The Message) read by Jeany Bien
18:30 - 19:35 - Prayer
19:56 - 22:17 - Song MP 1076 Jesus be the centre
23:14 - 23:36 - 2nd Reading Luke 13.34 read by Kitty Bird Jesus said, ‘Jerusalem…How often have I desired to gather your children together as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you were not willing!’
23:42 - 29:54 - Short talk: ‘Mothering – instinct to protect’ Linking to the reading where Jesus pictures himself as a mother hen. The instinct of protecting their young is shared among animals, including elephants, lions, cows, and birds. It's important to respect animals' protective instincts when we come close to them. Jesus longs to protect the human family and lead them into a better way of security, safety, peace, and dignity. Imagine ourselves and other people as little chicks or goslings under the wing of Jesus. Mothering Sunday is not just about celebrating biological mothers but also all kinds of people who care and protect others. The importance of empathy and understanding in mothering. The speaker encourages the audience to think about how they can protect and care for others.
30:39 - 33:52 - Song MP 583 Safe in the shadow of the Lord
35:20 - 36:02 - 3rd reading Matthew 12.46-50 NIVUK read by Kitty Bird 46 While Jesus was still talking to the crowd, his mother and brothers stood outside, wanting to speak to him. 47 Someone told him, ‘Your mother and brothers are standing outside, wanting to speak to you.’ 48 He replied, ‘Who is my mother, and who are my brothers?’ 49 Pointing to his disciples, he said, ‘Here are my mother and my brothers. 50 For whoever does the will of my Father in heaven is my brother and sister and mother.’
36:09 - 36:44 - 4th Reading: John 19.26-27 read by Jeany Bien 26 When Jesus saw his mother there, and the disciple whom he loved standing near by, he said to her, ‘Woman, here is your son,’ 27 and to the disciple, ‘Here is your mother.’ From that time on, this disciple took her into his home.
36:52 - 45:22 - Short Talk: ‘God’s new family’ Jesus welcomes all who follow him to be part of God's family. People in church who show care and interest in others make a difference. The church family can have arguments and divisions, but we are part of an amazing family of God. Jesus entrusted his mother to John to care for her and play his part in the family of God. We give thanks for mothers, physical or adoptive, as well as fathers who may play a maternal role. Men and women can share the role of being a mother to their children. We give thanks for brothers and sisters in the family of God, as well as children and those who have cared for us. Mothering Sunday can be an emotional day with many different emotions.
48:02 - 52:02 - Hymn R&S 41 For the beauty of the earth (Tune: 575)
52:07 - 01:01:03 - All age Activity: ‘connected as one family’
01:01:24 - 01:03:51 - Hymn R&S 518 Father I place into your hands
01:03:57 - Prayers Leader: God who is father and mother to us all, All: We place them in your hands.
01:08:12 - Lord’s Prayer (modern version)
01:09:20 - 01:12:04 - Hymn R&S 531 Lord of all hopefulness
01:12:04 - 01:12:30 - Blessing
01:12:58 - 01:16:33 - Music, photos , and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 12th March 2023 - 3rd Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 12th March 2023 - 3rd Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
05:05 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
05:23 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle led by Linda Curley
06:33 - Call to worship led by Linda Curley We come to God rejoicing: We bring our thanks and praise. We come to God with our needs and concerns: We bring our hopes and prayers.
06:51 - 11:07 - Hymn R&S 39 All creatures of our God and King (vs 1-4 only)
11:39 - 12:59 - Reading: Psalm 95. 1 – 7 (adapted) read by Abigail Lokko
13:18 - 14:48 - Introduction to the theme: ‘water of life’ Reading: John 4. 5 – 8 NIVUK read by Rosemary Taylor
14:50 - 16:39 - Prayer Lord's Prayer
16:48 - 19:25 - Song MP God forgave my sin in Jesus’ name
19:53 - 26:26 - Talk for all ages: ‘Wells, water and well-being’ The story of Jesus meeting a Samaritan at a well and the importance of water in our lives. Water has been treated with great respect throughout history and is often seen as a holy place linked to particular local saints with healing miracles. A church in Bierton, North of Aylesbury, linked to a Christian woman from medieval times called Asif. Rivers, especially chalk streams, are important for wildlife and need to be looked after for the benefit of both wildlife and ourselves. Sewage is sometimes dumped into our rivers, which is surely a disgrace to our nation. The psalm used in the service reminds us that the planet belongs to God and the oceans belong to God, their maker. A new high seas treaty by the United Nations to create large protected areas of the oceans to safeguard marine biodiversity. Water is a key theme in Lent this year with support for Water Aid, which provides clean water and sanitation to many poor communities around the world. The effects of climate change on water supplies in many poorer nations and the need to create water and sanitation services that last and can come back quickly online after a climate hazard. Women's voices and experiences are essential in adapting to climate change, and they must be heard and acted upon.
26:35 - 29:01 - Hymn R&S 572 Colours of day
29:17 - 31:03 - Reading: John 4.6 - 15 read by Norma Garden
31:18 - 34:20 - Hymn R&S 349 I heard the voice
34:50 - 37:50 - Reading: John 4.16 – 30 NIVUK read by Abigail Lokko
38:19 - 44:11- Short Address Wells are significant places in the Bible, and many important meetings took place at wells. Jacob's Well, located in modern-day Palestine, is the most famous well in the Bible. Maria, who lives in a small island in El Salvador, has to travel to the mainland every day to fetch water because there is no mains water on her island. Many women in low-income countries have to do this kind of work every day. In the encounter between Jesus and the Samaritan woman, both were thirsty and had to act to quench their thirst. The physical and spiritual aspects of our lives are intertwined and essential to our well-being. The American theologian Sally McFague believed that the interconnection of our souls and bodies brings us life in all its fullness. We should value both physical and spiritual water as essential to our life and well-being. We should recognize and accept everyone as brother and sister, as well as being accepted as a child of God. We should be thirsty for the Water of Life.
followed by 2 or 3 minutes of quiet reflection on these questions: - Do we welcome and value both the physical water and the spiritual water as essential to our life and well-being? - What do they teach us about recognising and accepting everyone as brother and sister? - What do we learn for ourselves about being accepted as brother or sister, and a child of God? - Are we thirsty for the water of life?
44:29 - 46:35 - Hymn R&S 543 Lead us heavenly Father lead us
46:45 - 48:42 - Reading: John 4.31 – 42 NIVUK read by Norma Garden
49:11 - 54:02 - Prayers for the world led by Sue Thorne
54:12 - 57:46 - Hymn R&S 579 Lord thy Church on earth
57:48 - 58:18 - Blessing
58:52 - 01:01:40 - Music, photos , and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 5th March 2023 - 2nd Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 5th March 2023 - 2nd Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
Worship and Communion led by Terry Hinks Organist: Andrew Winton
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
07:55 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
10:13 - Call to worship We come to worship you, Lord, the maker of our lives. We come to meet you, Lord, the keeper of our lives. We come to hear you, Lord, the wisdom in our lives. We come to follow you, Lord, the guider of our lives.
11:06 - 13:36 - Hymn - R&S 67 Immortal, invisible, God only wise
13:42 - Prayers of adoration and confession
15:30 - 28:51 - All age talk: ‘Help! I need somebody!’ The Beatles and their song "Help" as an example of asking for help. What helps you get through the day - things like daily devotions, friends, family, and nature. The importance of turning to God for help, as well as offering help to others. The Jars of Change appeal, which involves setting aside money over Lent to donate to the charity. The charity's focus this year is on providing clean water and sanitation to communities in need. Stories of two young women who have benefited from the charity's work. The idea of giving and helping others, even in small ways. A reminder that help can come from God and from our willingness to offer help to others.
29:18 - 30:16 - Reading: Psalm 121 NIVUK read by Ian Bogart I lift up my eyes to the mountains – where does my help come from? 2 My help comes from the Lord, the Maker of heaven and earth. 3 He will not let your foot slip – he who watches over you will not slumber; 4 indeed, he who watches over Israel will neither slumber nor sleep. 5 The Lord watches over you – the Lord is your shade at your right hand; 6 the sun will not harm you by day, nor the moon by night. 7 The Lord will keep you from all harm – he will watch over your life; 8 the Lord will watch over your coming and going both now and for evermore.
31:00 - 33:37 - Hymn - R&S 64 I lift my eyes to the quiet hills
33:44 - Introduction to the reading
34:47 - 37:13 - Reading: John 3.1-17 NIVUK
37:34 - 39:39 - Hymn - MP 619 Such love
39:43 - 53:26 - Short Address: The Repair Shop and the team of experts who restore old and broken items. In August 2021, the team met with Prince Charles and learned about his foundation's work in training young craftspeople. Charles gave the team a piece of pottery made for Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee and an 18th-century clock to repair. Jay Blades, one of the show's hosts, grew up in Hackney, and he and Charles bonded over their shared interests in apprenticeships and heritage crafts. The encounter between Nicodemus and Jesus in the Bible is similar to the meeting of Blades and Charles in that it brings together people from different backgrounds who share common interests. Nicodemus is a Pharisee and a member of the ruling council in Jerusalem who comes to meet Jesus at night. Nicodemus recognizes that God is at work in Jesus's ministry and life. Jesus tells Nicodemus that he must be born again to see the kingdom of God. This spiritual rebirth is about a fundamental change that enables us to see the kingdom of love, justice, and peace where God is at the center. Jesus teaches that his followers must become like little children to enter the kingdom of heaven. The kingdom of heaven is a place where God is at the center and all are of equal worth in the eyes of God.
53:30 - 58:22 - Prayers for the world with the response So, God of compassion: open our hearts, to welcome all.
58:23 - Prayer of Dedication of all our gifts
01:01:41 - Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ. A Prayer of thanksgiving and Lord’s Prayer
Distribution of bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice)
Closing Prayer
01:08:27 - 01:11:02 - Hymn R&S 345 Guide me O thou Great Jehovah
01:11:03 - 01:11:32 - Blessing
01:11:58 - 01:15:16 - Music, photos , and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 26th February 2023 - 1st Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 26th February 2023 - 1st Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
Worship led by Richard Goldstraw Organist: Charles Brewster
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
02:26 - Welcome and lighting of the peace candle
04:29 - Call to worship
05:27 - 09:30 - Hymn – Praise to the holiest – Tune Gerontius
09:38 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
12:30 - 15:35 - Talk for all ages The meaning and history of Lent, a season of penitence and self-denial observed to prepare for the Easter celebration. The importance of prayer, self-examination, and repentance during this period, as well as reading and meditating on God's word. A creative Lent daily program, which includes different activities for each day of the week Sunday: Social media fast Monday: Keep silence for at least 10 minutes Tuesday: Do a prayer walk around your neighborhood Wednesday: Fast your way (in a manner that is appropriate for your personal circumstances and needs) Thursday: Connect with a friend by calling, texting, or sending an email Friday: Read and reflect on God's holy word Saturday: Rest and refresh. Lent is our opportunity to grow in faith and devotion to Christ.
16:26 - 20:58 - Hymn – Dear Lord and Father
22:02 - Introduction to Bible readings
22:35 - 24:18 - Readings: Psalm 32 NIVUK
24:40 - 26:11 - Matthew 4:1-11
27:29 - 29:42 - Hymn R&S 543– Lead us heavenly Father Lead Us
29:48 - 41:05 - Sermon followed by time of quiet reflection Drawing inspiration from the hymn "Father Lead Me Day by Day" and Jesus' identity affirmation from God during his baptism. The assurance of being saved by grace is necessary in our lives. The promises of God should be hidden in our hearts to remain steadfast during temptations. The full armor of God should be worn to stand firm against the devil's schemes. Jesus defeated Satan on the cross, and we must use his name to resist temptations. Jesus' response to temptations was quoting the word of God. The spirit drives us into unusual and unexplored places. The spirit is at work whenever people speak the language of love, dream of a new community, and reach out to one another. God is gracious and picks us up when we stumble and fall into ditches along the way. Nothing in all creation can separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus, and goodness is stronger than evil, love is stronger than hate. As children of God, we need to have the promises of God hidden in our hearts and be sure of our identity in Him. Temptations will come, but we can stand firm by putting on the full armor of God and using the Word of God to resist the devil's schemes. The Spirit may also drive us into unusual and unexplored places, and we need to be open to following His leading. Ultimately, we can take comfort in the fact that nothing can separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus, and victory is ours through Him who loves us.
42:45 - 44:28 - Hymn – In my life Lord, Be Glorified
44:33 - 50:09 - Prayers for others and ourselves
51:59 - 55:40 - Hymn– O Jesus I have promised – Tune Hatherop
56:19 - 56:40 - Closing blessing
57:01 - 01:02:24 - Music, photos , and notices after the service

Summarised with #ChatGPT

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 19th February 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
08:00 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
08:20 - Welcome and lighting of the peace candle
10:28 - Call to worship Exalt the Lord our God and worship at his holy mountain, for the Lord our God is holy. Grace and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ
10:56 - 14:37 - Hymn - MP 77 Christ triumphant
14:40 - Opening Prayer of praise with the response God of glory (truth), to you We offer our worship and praise.
17:35 - Lord’s Prayer (modern version)
18:18 - Introduction: ‘what just happened?’ The importance of paying attention and being good witnesses in our daily lives. A scene from Sherlock Holmes to illustrate how we often do things without noticing.
25:43 - 27:09 - Readings: Exodus 24.12-18 NIVUK
27:23 - 36:34 - Short Talk: ‘A mountain top experience’ The story of Moses and the giving of the Ten Commandments is a significant moment in the faith story. The invitation from God for Moses to come up the mountain was initially frightening but is seen as gracious. Mountains have been sacred places in many different cultures and faiths, and they speak of powers beyond our own. The Holy God is described as a mystery, appearing as cloud, blazing light, and fire. The law that Moses was given on the mountain would make the Israelites a holy people as they live by the Commandments of honoring God and loving their neighbor. Moses stayed on the mountain for 40 days and 40 nights, which is significant in both the Old and New Testaments. Lent is a period of 40 days, leading up to the eve of Easter, and represents a journey towards the Mountaintop of Easter day. The signs of spring, such as snowdrops, are a symbol of God's renewing love and a reminder of the presence of Jesus. The prayer at the end of the passage is a reminder to seek hope and peace during the darker days and to be enlightened on our journey through Lent and beyond.
36:44 - 40:03 - Hymn - 454 Majesty, worship his majesty
40:32 - 41:57 - Reading: Matthew 17. 1 – 9 (The Message)
42:36 - 44:22 - Hymn - MP 545 Open our eyes Lord (sung twice seated)
45:20 - 47:13 - Reflection: ‘After the event’ Peter, James and John remember "Brothers of thunder"
48:18 - 51:19 - Hymn - MP 1227 The splendour of the King
51:22 - 01:00:35 - Short talk: ‘wonderers, worshippers and witnesses’ The topic of reflection is the story of the three disciples who went up the mountain with Jesus and witnessed the splendor of God. A reflection on four words related to the story of Jesus and his disciples on the mountain: wonder, worship, witness, and work. Wonder: Take a step back and wonder at the mysteries of God's presence, creation, and scripture during the season of Lent. Worship: The disciples' worship involved listening to Jesus, listen deeply to Jesus in scripture as the heart of worship. Witness: Witness to the reality of Jesus with humility and through both words and actions. Work: The disciples were invited to be part of the work of Jesus, we should pray for and participate in God's work in the world today.
The disciples' experience on the mountain was a revelation of divine light that they could not put into words. The disciples' response was to worship, but they had a lot to learn about true worship, which involves following and listening to Jesus. Listening to Jesus is at the heart of worship and is an essential aspect of our tradition. After wandering, worshiping, and listening, we are called to be witnesses of Jesus, but our witness can be mistaken if we fail to witness to the reality of Jesus. Witnessing requires humility and a deep understanding of the love of God. We are encouraged to pray for God's work in the world and for our part in it.
Prayer Activity ending with shared prayer
All our prayers, silent and spoken we bring to you, God of life and light. Help us to know the love of Jesus, to see his hidden glory, shining all around. Amen.
01:00:47 - 01:04:24 - Hymn - MP 728 We have a gospel to proclaim
01:04:26 - 01:04:48 - Blessing
01:05:13 - 01:10:30 - Music, notices and photos
Summarised with #ChatGPT
